THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
      In the Matter of Mark Douglas
      Lattimore,       
      Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25882
Submitted October 5, 2004 - Filed October 
  25, 2004

DISBARRED


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior 
  Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary 
  Counsel. 
J. Steedley Bogan, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent 
  and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement 
  for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the 
  agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to either an indefinite 
  suspension or disbarment.Â  We accept the agreement and disbar respondent from 
  the practice of law in this state.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, 
  are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Respondent was admitted to the practice 
  of law in North Carolina in 1996 and the practice of law in South Carolina in 
  1998.Â  From 1998 until 2000, he worked as an associate for the law firm of Forquer 
  & Green in the firmâ€™s Charlotte office.Â  In 2000, respondent formed the 
  partnership of Forquer, Green & Lattimore with offices in Greenville and 
  Charleston.Â  In 2001, the firm of Forquer, Lattimore & Calloway was formed 
  to succeed Forquer & Green in Charlotte.Â  Neither Forquer, Green, nor Calloway 
  are licensed to practice law in South Carolina. 
The primary business of Forquer, 
  Green & Lattimore was residential real estate closing services.Â  Respondent 
  worked out of the Greenville office from early 2001 until August 2003.Â  The 
  firm employed various associates licensed in South Carolina until its dissolution 
  upon respondentâ€™s departure.Â Â  
I.
On December 17, 2002, respondent 
  conducted a residential real estate closing for Client A.Â  For her convenience, 
  respondent traveled from his office in Greenville to Anderson to conduct the 
  closing.Â  Respondent did not bring any witnesses to the closing and conducted 
  the closing with only Client A present.Â  Upon his return to the office, non-lawyers 
  signed as witnesses and notary on the closing documents.Â  
Respondent acknowledges that non-lawyers 
  signing closing documents as witness or notary when they were not present at 
  the closing was routine in his office, especially during a period of high volume 
  that occurred as a result of the low interest rates from 2002 through 2004.Â  
  Respondent further admits that, on occasion, his staff would witness and notarize 
  documents prior to closing and prior to execution by the signatory.Â  Respondent 
  states this practice violated his own policies and procedures, but acknowledges 
  he is responsible.Â  
In the Greenville office during 
  this high volume period, non-lawyers conducted real estate closings outside 
  the presence of a licensed attorney.Â  Although respondent had policies in place 
  against this practice, he acknowledges it did occur and that he is responsible 
  for creating an environment in which the practice was tacitly condoned.Â  
II.
Respondent failed to complete his 
  mandatory continuing legal education (CLE) requirements for 2002.Â  He filed 
  an incomplete reporting affidavit with the Commission on Continuing Legal Education 
  and Specialization (the Commission).Â  On February 7, 2003, respondent was served 
  with a notice from the Commission that his licensed to practice law was suspended 
  as of February 5, 2003, for failing to meet mandatory CLE requirements.Â  Respondent 
  subsequently obtained the credits needed for compliance and filed an amended 
  affidavit.Â  His administrative suspension was lifted on February 26, 2003.
While suspended, respondent continued 
  to practice law.Â  Eighty-four closings were conducted in the Greenville office 
  during the twenty-one days in which respondent was suspended.Â  During this period 
  of time, no licensed attorneys worked in the Greenville office.Â  Respondent 
  acknowledges he was aware he was suspended and not permitted to practice law, 
  but nevertheless admits he made a conscious decision to continue to do so.Â  

III.
In August 2001, respondent conducted 
  a real estate closing in which Clients B & C sold one of two adjacent lots 
  they owned.Â  The lot sold had a house on it; the adjacent lot was empty.Â  As 
  a result of errors in the title search, the closing documents conveyed and encumbered 
  the empty lot rather than the lot with the house that the clients had intended 
  to sell.Â  
In Spring 2002, respondent was informed 
  of the error.Â  Respondent corrected the problem by having the clients and the 
  buyer sign reciprocal deeds.Â  Respondent failed, however, to secure a release 
  of the empty lot from the buyerâ€™s mortgage company until July 2003, after receiving 
  notice of the grievance filed by Client B and C.Â  This caused a several month 
  delay in Client B and Câ€™s sale of the empty lot to a new buyer.Â  Respondent 
  failed to adequately communicate with Client B and C during the time he was 
  attempting to solve the problems.
IV.
On January 9, 2003, respondent conducted a real estate 
  closing in which Client D and E were selling their home to buyer.Â  Through no 
  fault of respondent, the lender did not fund the loan and the transaction had 
  to be cancelled. 
When the problems were resolved, the closing 
  was rescheduled for February 11, 2003.Â  Respondent conducted the second closing 
  even though he was aware his license to practice law was suspended.Â  Respondentâ€™s 
  partner, Green, was present in the office when the loan was closed, but Green 
  was not licensed to practice law in this state.Â  Respondent failed to sign some 
  of the closing documents.Â  A non-lawyer in the office subsequently signed respondentâ€™s 
  name to the closing documents without indicating someone was signing for him.Â  
  This was not done with respondentâ€™s specific authorization, however, respondent 
  acknowledges he was responsible for creating an environment in which non-lawyers 
  in his office would assume the practice was acceptable.Â  
V.
From March 2001 through July 2002, 
  the Greenville office of Forquer, Green & Lattimore conducted 166 closings 
  in which National City Mortgage was the lender.Â  In instances in which the loans 
  were for refinancing rather than purchase money purposes, representatives of 
  the lender insisted that the closing be done prior to completion of the title 
  search and the title work be done during the three-day recession period.Â  Respondent 
  advised the borrowers in these cases that the title search had not been conducted 
  and that the closings would not be completed or the loans funded until the title 
  work was complete.Â  Respondent instructed the borrowers to sign closing documents 
  without property descriptions.Â  The property descriptions would be added once 
  the title work was complete.Â  This process was contrary to the firmâ€™s standard 
  practice and, as a result, the post-closing process in many of the files was 
  not timely handled.Â  In forty-eight of the National City files, the mortgages 
  were not recorded as of January 2003.Â  By the time respondent was contacted 
  by National City Mortgage, many of the mortgages had been lost and had to be 
  re-executed.Â  
It was the firmâ€™s practice to collect 
  the title insurance policy premium from the closing and then issue a separate 
  check once respondent issued the title opinion.Â  Forquer visited the office 
  periodically to collect the premium checks.Â  It was his responsibility to pay 
  the premium over to the title company which would then issue the policy.Â  In 
  approximately eighty-four of the National City Mortgage closings, premiums were 
  collected, but policies were not issued. 
VI.
Respondent received a significant 
  portion of his business in Anderson from three mortgage loan brokerage companies.Â  
  Certain employees and owners of these mortgage loan brokerage companies conspired 
  with certain loan officers employed by National City Mortgage and certain real 
  estate appraisers to obtain loans on properties for more than the properties 
  were worth using inflated appraisals.Â  (The mortgage brokers, loan officers, 
  and appraisers are referred to collectively as â€œCo-Conspirators.â€).Â  Respondent 
  conduct the closings on many of the properties involved in the conspiracy.Â  

In several instances, the Co-Conspirators 
  obtained the fraudulent loans by using a practice known as property â€œflipping.â€Â  
  In an illegal property flip, a straw buyer or co-conspirator (Buyer A) will 
  enter into a contract to purchase property for its actual value from the Seller.Â  
  Buyer A will not obtain financing but will, instead, enter into a contract to 
  sell the property to a co-conspirator (Buyer B) at an inflated price.Â  Buyer 
  B will then use an appraisal for the inflated price to obtain a loan.Â  Closings 
  on the sale from Seller to Buyer A and from Buyer A to Buyer B are done at the 
  same time.Â  Buyer A will pay the contract price to Seller from the loan proceeds 
  and will then often split the difference with Buyer B.Â  The actual transaction 
  is contrary to the information contained on the HUD-1 forms, which misrepresents 
  the sales prices and the source of the funding for the purchases and often falsely 
  indicates that the buyers are contributing significant down payments in cash.Â  
  According to the Agreement for Discipline by Consent, when no payments are made 
  to the lender and the property is foreclosed, the lender can recoup only the 
  actual value of the property rather than the amount loaned on the inflated appraisal.Â  

An illegal property flip generally 
  requires the conspiracy of at least one of the buyers, an appraiser, and a mortgage 
  broker or loan officer.Â  It also requires the assistance of an attorney who 
  is aware of the fraud, chooses to look the other way, or who fails to supervise 
  non-lawyer assistants engaging in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  In order 
  for the flip to work, the same attorney has to close both transactions.Â  If 
  an attorney conducts a closing on property for a certain sales price and funds 
  that closing with proceeds from the immediate resale of the same property for 
  a significantly higher amount, the attorney has constructive notice that the 
  second sale might be based on a fraudulently inflated appraisal of the property.Â  
  This is particularly true when the buyer leaves the closing with both the property 
  and with money from the loan.Â  
In the case of the loans closed 
  by respondent, in addition to the constructive notice described above, respondent 
  had actual knowledge in at least two of the transactions that the appraisals 
  were inflated.Â  In several of the transactions, respondent falsely represented 
  on closing documents that mortgage broker fees to a Co-Conspirator were payments 
  to creditors of the borrower.Â  
Respondent was on further notice 
  that the conduct of the Co-Conspirators might be illegal because, in connection 
  with several of the closings, the documents reflected that the loans were for 
  refinancing rather than purchase money.Â  At the same time, respondent prepared 
  documents actually conveying the property.Â  Additionally, at least one Co-Conspirator 
  who was personally known to respondent used aliases to obtain some of the loans.Â  

The Co-Conspirators used 116 fraudulent 
  appraisals, each of which had been inflated by at least $50,000 to obtain loans 
  from National City Mortgage.Â  The Co-Conspirators pled guilty to federal felony 
  conspiracy charges and admitted to obtaining inflated amounts totaling $13,000,000.
Respondent closed eighty-eight 
  loans for the Co-Conspirators with inflated appraisals of at least $25,000 each.Â  
  Respondent did not share in the profits from the fraudulently obtained loans, 
  but he did benefit from significant business generated by the various mortgage 
  brokers involved.Â  Additionally, respondent charged a fee of $175 for the title 
  search on each closing.Â  In cases of flip transactions done simultaneously on 
  the same property, there is no need for a second title search.Â  Respondent essentially 
  double-billed for this work.Â  
 On June 3, 2004, respondent pled 
  guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit mail fraud in the United States 
  District Court arising out of his involvement in the above-described activities 
  relating to the National City Mortgage loans.Â  As of the date of the Agreement 
  for Discipline by Consent, respondent had not been sentenced.Â  
VII.
Respondent conducted a closing on 
  a refinancing loan for Client F in September 2002.Â  Respondent issued and mailed 
  a check to Client Fâ€™s existing lender to pay off her mortgage.Â  In December 
  2002, Client F received a notice from her lender that payment had not been received.Â  
  When respondent received a copy of this notice, he reissued payment to the lender 
  with a request that it apply the payment retroactively to September.Â  The lender 
  would not comply with this request and returned the check as insufficient to 
  pay the debt.Â  In March 2003, Client F received a delinquency notice.Â  At that 
  time, respondent paid the full amount claimed by the lender using his firmâ€™s 
  funds to make up the shortage.Â  
Although respondent maintained a 
  separate trust account for the Greenville office and kept some financial records 
  there, primary bookkeeping and account reconciliation were conducted by non-lawyers 
  in the Charlotte office.Â  Respondent did not supervise this process and was 
  not informed of discrepancies in the trust account.Â  Additionally, non-lawyers 
  in respondentâ€™s Greenville office often placed checks returned by lenders and 
  deeds or mortgages returned by the RMC office into the closing files without 
  alerting respondent to the problem.Â  For these reasons, respondent was unaware 
  that the two checks issued to Client Fâ€™s lender did not clear the bank in a 
  timely fashion but sat non-negotiated in Client Fâ€™s file.Â  It was not until 
  Client F contacted respondent with her delinquency notices that respondent took 
  action to correct the situation.Â  
VIII.
At the request of Client Gâ€™s lender, 
  the Greenville office conducted a closing for Client G in July 2001.Â  Due to 
  miscommunication on the lenderâ€™s part, both respondentâ€™s firm (on behalf of 
  Client G) and the lender ordered title searches on the property.Â  Respondent 
  issued a title opinion and paid out funds from the closing for his title search 
  and for a title policy.Â  When the lender learned it would have to pay for the 
  title work it conducted, the lender demanded respondent reimburse it for this 
  expense, claiming respondent was hired solely to â€œwitnessâ€ the closing.
Initially, respondent refused 
  to refund the money, asserting his firmâ€™s policies prohibited â€œwitness-onlyâ€ 
  closings and required their own title work.Â  In order to maintain a good working 
  relationship with the lender, however, respondent decided to pay $500 to share 
  in the loss.Â  The check to Client Gâ€™s lender was written on the Greenville officeâ€™s 
  operating account.Â  The check was returned for insufficient funds.Â  Respondent 
  was unable to explain the deficiency because all accounting and bookkeeping 
  for the operating account had been transferred to the Charlotte office.Â  The 
  firm ultimately paid the lender $500 plus bank fees incurred as a result of 
  the returned check.Â  
IX.
In October 2002, respondent conducted 
  a loan closing for Client G.Â  At the closing, he withheld an estimated payment 
  for the property taxes that would become due in January 2003.Â  In January 2003, 
  payment was issued to the tax authority for the amount withheld, however, the 
  estimate was lower than the actual taxes due.Â  Client G contacted respondentâ€™s 
  office in June 2003 to inform him that she had received a delinquent tax notice.Â  
  Payment was reissued in the full amount with respondentâ€™s firm paying the difference.Â  
  Client G made numerous attempts to get information from respondent about the 
  status of her tax payment.Â  She had no success.Â  In fact, at the time she filed 
  her disciplinary complaint, the matter had been resolved but respondent had 
  failed to inform Client G.Â  
Respondent acknowledges that, due 
  to his insufficient supervision of the firmâ€™s accounting practices, he was unaware 
  the tax check did not clear the bank for six months.Â  He acknowledges that the 
  volume of real estate closings he was attempting to accomplish in the Greenville 
  office led to misfiling and misplacing important documents such as the trust 
  account check that was returned by the tax office.Â  Respondent further acknowledges 
  that his delegation of the responsibility to respond to Client Gâ€™s inquiries 
  was not sufficient to meet his obligation to adequately communicate with his 
  client.Â  
X.
In April 2002, respondent conducted 
  a closing on the sale of property from Mr. H to Mr. I.Â  In the transaction, 
  Mr. H was selling a portion of a tract of land encumbered by a mortgage owed 
  by Mr. H.Â  The agreement provided Mr. Hâ€™s lender would accept $35,000 in exchange 
  for a release of the portion of the property being purchased by Mr. I.Â  Mr. 
  I obtained a loan on the property and, by June 2003, had paid it off.Â  Mr. I 
  then attempted to borrow additional funds using the property as collateral.Â  
  In the course of closing on this second loan, it was discovered that Mr. Hâ€™s 
  mortgage still encumbered the portion of the property now owned by Mr. I.Â  
In May 2002, after the closing on 
  the sale from Mr. H to Mr. I, respondent had issued payment to Mr. Hâ€™s lender.Â  
  However, the lender did not accept the payment or release its mortgage because 
  certain documentary requirements had not been met by respondent at the time 
  of the closing.Â  Respondentâ€™s file contains no record of receiving the check 
  back from the lender, although the lender did produce a cover letter indicating 
  that it had sent the check back.Â  The firm ultimately paid $35,000 plus interest 
  to the lender and obtained a release of Mr. Iâ€™s portion of the property.Â Â  
 From the time of the closing in 
  April 2002 until payment was made in August 2003, the balance in respondentâ€™s 
  trust account remained sufficient to cover the $35,000 withheld from the closing.Â  
  Respondent admits that his failure to adequately supervise the firmâ€™s trust 
  accounting procedures resulted in his failure to know that the check to Mr. 
  Hâ€™s lender had never cleared the bank.Â  He also acknowledges that the volume 
  of real estate closings he was attempting to accomplish in the Greenville office 
  led to misfiling and misplacing important documents such as the payoff check 
  that Mr. Hâ€™s lender returned.Â  
XI.
For each of the law offices in which 
  closings on South Carolina properties were handled (Greenville, Rock Hill, Charleston, 
  and Charlotte), Robert Forquer and Scott Green opened a bank account called 
  the â€œrecordingâ€ account.Â  When funds were collected at closing to pay fees for 
  the recording of mortgages, deeds, and other documents, a check in the amount 
  collected would be written from the real estate trust account and deposited 
  into the recording account for that office.Â  Checks to the appropriate county 
  office would, in turn, be written from the recording account and delivered with 
  the documents to be filed.Â  The firm routinely and intentionally overcharged 
  clients for these recording fees and failed to reimburse the amounts not used 
  for the designated purpose.Â  The overcharges ranged from $2.00 to $40.00 per 
  closing.Â  
The recording accounts were also 
  sometimes used for processing the entire closing.Â  The firm failed to maintain 
  sufficient records of the recording accounts and failed to identify and track 
  client funds maintained in the accounts.Â  No record was kept in the closing 
  files of the actual amounts paid for recording fees and no accounting of overcharges 
  to the clients was kept.Â  The overcharges for the recording fees were separate 
  from the attorneyâ€™s fees and courier fees charged to clients.Â  
The funds in the recording accounts 
  were used for a variety of purposes other than document recording fees, including 
  office expenses (stamps, bank charges, staff lunches), correction of errors 
  in closings (payoff shortages and miscalculation of title insurance premiums), 
  settlement of minor claims against the firm, payroll or other payments to staff, 
  and checks to Mr. Forquer and Mr. Green in various amounts, including checks 
  for $4,000 and $7,000.
The source of the funds in the recording 
  accounts (client charges and overcharges for recording fees) was insufficient 
  to cover the firmâ€™s uses of the account.Â  As a result, the accounts were frequently 
  short of funds.Â  Mortgages, deeds, and other closing documents were routinely 
  held and not timely filed because there were insufficient funds in the recording 
  account to pay the recording fees.Â  Occasionally, associates used their own 
  money to pay recording fees and then sought reimbursement from the firm.Â  
In the Greenville office, a paralegal 
  with signatory authority on the recording and real estate trust accounts wrote 
  a series of approximately twenty-five checks payable to herself or to cash in 
  various amounts.Â  This paralegal was also responsible for reconciling the recording 
  account and maintaining records associated with it.Â  Upon receipt of the cancelled 
  checks, the paralegal altered the payee to make it appear that the checks had 
  been written to county offices for legitimate purposes.Â  Using this method, 
  the paralegal took approximately $46,000 from the recording account.Â  
Although he was unaware of the paralegalâ€™s 
  activities in this regard, respondent had supervisory authority over the employee.Â  
  From February 2003 through May 2004, the Greenville recording account had insufficient 
  fund charges of approximately $11,522.Â  
Respondent acknowledges that the 
  recording accounts were client trust accounts.Â  He further acknowledges that, 
  as a partner in the Greenville, Charleston, and Charlotte offices, he shared 
  responsibility for the safekeeping of client funds and for maintaining certain 
  financial records.Â  Respondent acknowledges that the use to which his firm put 
  the recording account funds constituted mismanagement, commingling, and misappropriation.Â  

LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct 
  he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, 
  Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to 
  a client); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and 
  promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall 
  keep a client reasonably informed about the status of a matter and promptly 
  comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.15(a) (lawyer 
  shall hold property of clients in the lawyerâ€™s possession in connection with 
  a representation separate from the lawyerâ€™s own property); Rule 5.1 (partner 
  in a law firm shall make reasonable efforts to ensure that the firm has in effect 
  measures giving reasonable assurance that all lawyers in the firm conform to 
  the Rules of Professional Conduct); Â Â Rule 5.3(a) 
  (a partner in a law firm shall make reasonable efforts to ensure that 
  the firm has in effect measures giving reasonable assurance that a non-lawyer 
  employeeâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional obligations of the lawyer); 
  Rule 5.3(b) (lawyer having direct supervisory authority over a non-lawyer shall 
  make reasonable efforts to ensure that the personâ€™s conduct is compatible with 
  the professional obligations of the lawyer); Rule 5.3(c) (lawyer shall be responsible 
  for conduct of a non-lawyer that would be a violation of the Rules of Professional 
  Conduct if engaged in by a lawyer if either the lawyer orders or, with the knowledge 
  of the specific conduct, ratifies the conduct involved or the lawyer is a partner 
  in the law firm in which the non-lawyer is employed, or has direct supervisory 
  authority over the non-lawyer, and knows of the conduct at a time when its consequences 
  can be avoided or mitigated but fails to take remedial action); Rule 5.5(b) 
  (lawyer shall not assist a person who is not a member of the bar in the performance 
  of activity that constitutes the unauthorized practice of law); Rule 8.4(a) 
  (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional 
  Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (lawyer shall not commit a criminal act that reflects 
  adversely on the lawyer's honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in 
  other respects); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer 
  to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); 
  and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct 
  that is prejudicial to the administration of justice). 
In addition, respondent admits his conduct 
  violated Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent admits his misconduct is grounds for discipline 
  under Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it is a ground 
  for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 7(a)(4) 
  (it is a ground for discipline for lawyer to be convicted of a crime of moral 
  turpitude or a serious crime); Rule 7(a)(5) (it is a ground for discipline for 
  lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute administration of justice or 
  to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating 
  an unfitness to practice law); and Rule 7(a)(6) (it is a ground for discipline 
  for lawyer to violate oath of office).Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline 
  by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  Respondentâ€™s request that the disbarment 
  be made retroactive to the date he was placed on interim suspension is denied.Â Â Â  

Within fifteen (15) days of the date of 
  this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing 
  that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender 
  his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  

 DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT 
  and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Bert C. Atkinson and Stephanie S. Atkinson,       
Respondents-Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc.,       
Appellant-Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25883
Heard November 5, 2003 - Filed October 
  25, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
G. Dana Sinkler, of Warren and Sinkler, of Charleston; Michael W. Davis and 
  Robert N. Hochman, both of Sidley, Austin, Brown, & Wood, of Chicago, for 
  Appellant-Respondent.
Keating L. Simons, III, of Simons and Keaveny, of Charleston, for Respondents-Appellants.
      
    
  

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This cross-appeal arises 
  from an action brought by homeowners Bert and Stephanie Atkinson (Atkinsons) 
  against Orkin Exterminating Company (Orkin), seeking recovery for structural 
  damage to their home caused by termite infestation.Â  In this appeal, Orkin seeks 
  a remittitur of the punitive damages award, and the Atkinsons seek reversal 
  of the trial courtâ€™s decision to offset their compensatory damages by the amount 
  they received in a settlement from a third party. 
  [1] Â  After certifying this case from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 
  204(b), SCACR, we reverse and remand the issue concerning the amount of punitive 
  damages, with instructions, and reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision to offset 
  compensatory damages.  
Factual/Procedural Background
In the underlying action, the Atkinsons sued Orkin, 
  among others, for breach of contract with a fraudulent act and negligence.Â  

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Breach of Contract with a Fraudulent Act
When the Atkinsons purchased their home in 1995, 
  they discovered that the previous owners of the house had purchased and maintained 
  a termite bond from Orkin since 1972.Â  The documents comprising the termite 
  bond included a LIFETIME TERMITE DAMAGE GUARANTEE, which provided up to $100,000 
  in recoverable repair costs for termite damage at a fixed, renewable rate of 
  $28 per year (fixed-rate provision).Â  The guarantee also included a provision 
  that allowed customers to transfer the bond to any subsequent purchaser of the 
  house (transferability provision). Orkin categorizes this version of the LIFETIME 
  TERMITE DAMAGE GUARANTEE as a â€œpre-1975 contractâ€ because it provided benefits 
  and coverage not available to customers today. [2] Â  
Soon after the Atkinsons moved into their new home, 
  they attempted to have the termite bond transferred to them as permitted by 
  the transferability provision.Â  But, when the Atkinsons contacted Earl Beck 
  (Beck), then manager of Orkinâ€™s Charleston office, seeking to have the bond 
  transferred in their name, Beck refused.Â  Instead, Beck offered the Atkinsons 
  a new contract with less desirable terms.Â  The Atkinsons rejected the offer, 
  and Orkin canceled the termite bond in June 1996 for non-payment.Â  At trial, 
  Orkin admitted that it breached the contract when it refused to honor the transferability 
  provision. [3] 
Because Orkin refused to transfer the contract, 
  the Atkinsons obtained coverage from Terminix.Â  In August 1996, after Orkinâ€™s 
  protection had expired and while Terminixâ€™s bond was in force, the Atkinsons 
  discovered termites and termite damage in the structure of their house.Â  Terminix 
  denied full coverage, asserting that most of the termite damage took place during 
  the twenty-four years that Orkinâ€™s coverage applied.Â  
B.    Negligence
Before the Atkinsons purchased the house, Orkin conducted 
  a routine inspection and reported that the residence was free of termites and 
  termite damage.Â  Shortly after they moved into the house, the Atkinsons found 
  living termites and termite damage in a windowsill.Â  Further investigation revealed 
  termite damage in the structure of the house.
To determine the extent of the termite damage, the 
  Atkinsons hired Cam Lay of Clemson Universityâ€™s Department of Pesticide Regulation 
  (South Carolinaâ€™s regulatory agency for pest control businesses) to conduct 
  an additional inspection of the house.Â  Lay concluded that Orkin (1) failed 
  to report termite damage, (2) violated state regulatory standards by failing 
  to disclose powder-post-beetle damage and decay damage, and (3) failed to disclose 
  crawl-space-moisture readings.Â  At trial, Orkin admitted that it negligently 
  failed to disclose prior termite damage to the house in its inspection report 
  but denied the remaining allegations in Layâ€™s report.
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Orkinâ€™s 1980 Initiative
In 1980, Orkinâ€™s president wrote a memorandum outlining 
  an initiative that directed branch managers to raise the renewal rates of all 
  pre-1975 contracts in direct contradiction to the fixed-rate provision.Â  The 
  memo prescribed the manner in which managers were to deal with customers complaining 
  about rate increases.Â  It provided that if the customers mentioned a pamphlet 
  that Orkin sent to some customers to promote the fixed-rate provision, the managers 
  would ask the customers to read the fixed-rate language aloud, over the telephone.Â  
  If the customers repeated the language verbatim, the manager would tell them 
  that â€œa computer mistake was madeâ€ and that a corrected bill would be sent.Â  
  But if the customers did not repeat the language verbatim, the customers were 
  told that the rates were â€œeligible for increaseâ€ according to a â€œrecent legal 
  ruling.â€Â  At trial, over Orkinâ€™s objection, the judge allowed the Atkinsons 
  to submit this memo into evidence.Â Â  
Four years after Orkin began its initiative to 
  raise rates, the Federal Trade Commission (â€œFTCâ€) filed an administrative complaint 
  alleging that Orkinâ€™s unilateral renewal rate increase was an unfair trade practice.Â  
  In addition, the administrative law judge ordered Orkin to reimburse those customers 
  who paid increased rates pursuant to Orkinâ€™s initiative.Â  The Eleventh Circuit 
  Court of Appeals affirmed the ALJâ€™s ruling. Orkin Co., Inc. v. Federal Trade 
  Commâ€™n, 849 F.2d 1354 (11th Cir. 1988).
After Orkin was enjoined from raising rates on 
  its pre-1975 contracts, Orkin decided to change its advertising material as 
  to the transferability provision as well.Â  For many years, the renewal forms 
  Orkin sent to customers contained the statement, â€œ[i]f you sell your property 
  this protection can be transferred to the new owner.Â  An excellent selling point 
  for you.â€ Orkin removed this language from its renewal forms after the FTC ruling.Â  

At trial, Orkinâ€™s president admitted that the FTC 
  ruling caused Orkin to lose money and that the company had conducted â€œsome economic 
  analysisâ€ to determine its projected losses.Â  During discovery, Orkin did not 
  disclose any findings from that analysis. 
  [4] Â  In an attempt to show that Orkin had a financial incentive to breach 
  the transferability provision in its pre-1975 contracts, the Atkinsons retained 
  Dr. Perry Woodside (Woodside), an economist and business professor at the College 
  of Charleston, to project (1) Orkinâ€™s current and potential losses for honoring 
  the fixed-rate provision; and (2) Orkinâ€™s current and projected gain if Orkin 
  dishonored the transferability provision.Â  The Atkinsons offered Woodsideâ€™s 
  projections to show that Orkinâ€™s gain from breaching the transferability provision 
  would mitigate Orkinâ€™s losses due to the FTC ruling.Â  Over Orkinâ€™s objection, 
  the trial judge allowed Woodside to testify that Orkin could have sustained 
  â€œstaggeringâ€ losses amounting to $53,872,894 as a result of the FTC ruling.Â  
  In addition, Woodside testified that Orkin could realize a gain of $42,352,548 
  if it dishonored the transferability provision.Â  
The jury awarded $75,259.33 in compensatory damages 
  - $6,191 for the contract claim and $69,068.33 
  [5]  for the negligence claim.Â  The jury also awarded $786,500 in punitive 
  damages for the contract claim. [6] 
    
In a post-trial motion, 
  Orkin requested that the court reduce the Atkinsonsâ€™ damages award by the amount 
  recovered from the Atkinsonsâ€™ settlement with Terminix.Â  Because the trial judge 
  found that â€œTerminixâ€™s conduct could be a contributing factor in the neglience 
  cause of action and, thus, a contributing factor to Plaintiffâ€™s damages,â€ the 
  judge granted Orkinâ€™s motion for set-off.Â  The parties filed notices of cross-appeal 
  and submitted the following issues for review:

  I.                 
Was the punitive damages award so excessive as to violate Orkinâ€™s due 
  process rights? 
   
  II.              
Did the trial court err in offsetting the Atkinsonâ€™s judgment by the 
  amount received from the settlement with Terminix? 
   

Law/Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Due Process and Punitive Damages
The jury returned a verdict 
  finding Orkin liable for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act 
  and awarded $6,191 in compensatory damages and $786,500 in punitive damages, 
  a ratio of approximately approximately 127 to 1.Â  Orkin argues that the punitive 
  damages award was so excessive that it violated its right to due process.Â  We 
  agree.
The practice of awarding 
  punitive damages originated in principles of criminal law â€œto deter the wrongdoer 
  and others from committing like offenses in the future.â€ Laird v. Nationwide 
  Ins. Co., 243 S.C. 388, 393, 134 S.E.2d 206, 210 (1964).Â  Historically, 
  our courts have recognized that punitive damages are intended to punish a wrongdoer 
  when â€œcriminalâ€ conduct is intertwined with civil causes of action.Â  See 
  Dorsey D. Ellis, Jr., Fairness and Efficiency in the Law of Punitive Damages, 
  56 S. Cal. L. Rev. 1, 12-20 (1982) (describing how the court system has come 
  to approve public punishment in private actions by utilizing punitive damages).Â Â  
  This Court has held that â€œ[p]unitive damages also serve to vindicate a private 
  right to the injured party.â€¦â€ Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378, 529 
  S.E.2d 528, 533 (2000) (quoting Harris v. Burnside, 261 S.C. 190, 196, 
  199 S.E.2d 65, 68 (1973)).
The policy behind awarding 
  punitive damages must also remain consistent with the principle of penal theory 
  that the â€œpunishment should fit the crime.â€ Mathias v. Accor Economy Lodging 
  Inc. and Motel 6 Operating L.P., 347 F.3d 672, 676 (7th Cir. 2003).Â  â€œIn 
  sum, courts must ensure that the measure of punishment is both reasonable and 
  proportionate to the amount of harm to the plaintiff and to the general damages 
  recovered.â€Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Campbell, 538 
  U.S. 408, 426 (2003).Â  
Because punitive damages 
  are quasi-criminal in nature, the process of assessing punitive damages is subject 
  to the protections of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of 
  the United States Constitution.Â  The Due Process Clause insures that â€œa person 
  receive fair notice not only of the conduct that will subject him to punishment, 
  but also of the severity of the penalty that a State may impose.â€Â  BMW of 
  North America, Inc. v. Gore, 517 U.S. 559, 574 (1996).Â  In addition, a defendantâ€™s 
  right to reasonable notice should not be diminished simply because the defendant 
  is a deep pocket corporation. Id. at 585.Â  For example, in Gore, 
  the United States Supreme Court proclaimed, â€œ[t]he fact that BMW is a large 
  corporation rather than an impecunious individual does not diminish its entitlement 
  to fair notice of the demands that the several States impose on the conduct 
  of business.â€ Id.
After the parties submitted 
  their briefs in the present case, the United States Supreme Court issued its 
  opinion in State Farm v. Campbell, which considered whether a 
  punitive damages award was so excessive as to violate due process.Â  538 U.S. 
  at 416-429.Â  In Campbell, plaintiffs sued State Farm in a Utah trial 
  court for bad-faith failure to settle - a legal theory similar to South Carolinaâ€™s 
  bad faith (now negligent) failure to settle cause of action set forth in Tyger 
  River Pine Co. v. Maryland Cas. Co., 170 S.C. 286, 170 S.E. 346 (1933).Â  
  During trial, the judge allowed the plaintiffs to present evidence of other 
  instances around the nation in which State Farm had refused, in bad faith, to 
  settle a clientâ€™s claim.Â  
The Utah Supreme Court 
  noted that State Farm was being punished for its nationwide policies rather 
  than for the conduct in the Campbellsâ€™ case and reduced plaintiffsâ€™ punitive 
  damages award from $145 million to $25 million.Â  State Farm subsequently petitioned 
  the United States Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari, which the Court granted.Â  
  The Court held that the punitive damages award was so excessive as to violate 
  State Farmâ€™s due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment of the United 
  States Constitution.Â  Campbell, 538 U.S. at 429.
In determining the constitutionality 
  of the punitive damages award, the Campbell Court looked to three guideposts [7]  set forth in Gore: 

(1) the degree of reprehensibility of the defendantâ€™s misconduct; (2) the disparity 
  between the actual and potential harm suffered by the plaintiff and the punitive 
  damages award; and (3) the difference between the punitive damages awarded by 
  the jury and the civil penalties authorized or imposed in comparable cases.

Campbell, 538 U.S. at 418 (citing Gore, 517 U.S. at 575).Â  In 
  addition, the United States Supreme Court applied a de novo standard 
  of review and instructed appellate courts to so the same when reviewing punitive 
  damage awards. Â Campbell, 538 U.S. at 417 (citing Cooper Indus., Inc. 
  v. Leatherman Tool Group, Inc., 532 U.S. 424, 435-436 (2001)). 
In the present case, we 
  reverse and remand the issue of punitive damages because (1) the trial court 
  improperly admitted evidence that unfairly prejudices Orkinâ€™s case; and (2) 
  the award is so excessive that it constitutes an irrational and arbitrary deprivation 
  of property under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the 
  United States Constitution.
  1.     Degree of Reprehensibility of 
  Orkinâ€™s Misconduct  
Orkin argues that the trial 
  judge caused the degree of reprehensibility of Orkinâ€™s conduct to be unfairly 
  inflated by allowing the jury to consider evidence of Orkinâ€™s 1980 initiative 
  and Woodsideâ€™s expert testimony concerning Orkinâ€™s current and potential loss 
  for honoring the fixed-rate provision in all its pre-1975 contracts.Â  We agree.Â  

The first guidepost established 
  in Gore is the degree of reprehensibility of the defendantâ€™s misconduct, 
  which the United States Supreme Court held is â€œ[t]he most important indicium 
  of the reasonableness of a punitive damages award.â€¦â€ Gore, 517 U.S. at 
  575.Â  The United States Supreme Court has provided state courts with a list 
  of considerations to be used in determining the degree of reprehensibility of 
  a defendantâ€™s conduct:

the harm caused was physical 
  as opposed to economic; the tortious conduct evinced an indifference to or a 
  reckless disregard of the health and safety of others; the target of the conduct 
  had financial vulnerability; the conduct involved repeated actions or was an 
  isolated incident; and the harm was the result of intentional malice, trickery, 
  or deceit, or mere accident.
â€¦
The existence of any one of these 
  factors weighing in favor of a plaintiff may not be sufficient to sustain a 
  punitive damages award; and the absence of all of them renders any award suspect.

Campbell, 538 U.S. at 419.
We find the evidence of Orkinâ€™s 
  1980 initiative and Woodsideâ€™s expert testimony about the initiative unfairly 
  amplified the degree of reprehensibility of Orkinâ€™s conduct and, in turn, unfairly 
  inflated the amount of punitive damages the jury awarded.Â  
(a) Orkin Initiative Memo
The Atkinsons argue that Orkin, which was already 
  enjoined from breaching the fixed-rate provision, was searching for new ways 
  to mitigate the losses of its unprofitable pre-1975 contracts.Â  On the contrary, 
  Orkin contends that because the initiative was not related to the conduct in 
  the Atkinsonsâ€™ breach of contract claim, the trial judge erred in allowing the 
  memo to be admitted.Â  We agree with Orkin.Â  
The United States Supreme Court considered a similar 
  issue in Campbell.Â  During the damages phase, the trial judge allowed 
  the plaintiff to present evidence concerning State Farmâ€™s prior conduct, suggesting 
  that State Farm had developed a nationwide policy of denying claims and refusing 
  to settle claims in bad-faith.Â  The trial court not only allowed testimony of 
  State Farmâ€™s conduct toward the Campbells, it accepted testimony concerning 
  State Farmâ€™s denial of claims around the country.Â  Much of the evidence concerning 
  State Farmâ€™s out-of-state conduct was dissimilar and unrelated to State Farmâ€™s 
  conduct toward the Campbells.Â  Because of the dissimilarity in conduct, the 
  United States Supreme Court held that State Farmâ€™s out-of-state conduct was 
  not admissible to inflate the Campbellsâ€™ punitive damages award:

[t]he courts awarded punitive 
  damages to punish and deter conduct that bore no relation to the Campbellâ€™s 
  harm.Â  A defendantâ€™s dissimilar acts, independent from the acts upon which liability 
  was premised, may not serve as the basis for punitive damages.Â  A defendant 
  should be punished for the conduct that harmed the plaintiff, not for being 
  an unsavory individual or business.Â  Due process does not permit courts, in 
  the calculation of punitive damages, to adjudicate the merits of other partiesâ€™ 
  hypothetical claims against a defendant under the guise of reprehensibility 
  analysisÂ  
â€¦.
Punishment on these bases creates 
  the possibility of multiple punitive damages awards for the same conduct.

Campbell, 538 U.S. at 422-423.Â Â  
The â€œsimilarityâ€ analysis conducted in Campbell 
  arises from the same general relevance safeguards addressed by Rule 403, SCRE 
  (a court shall rule evidence inadmissible if its probative value is substantially 
  outweighed by its prejudicial value).Â  The analysis applied in Campbell, 
  however, requires us to determine, in the present case, whether evidence of 
  the 1980 initiative is â€œsimilar toâ€ the breach of the transferability provision.Â  
  In other words, unless Orkinâ€™s past conduct is â€œsimilarâ€ to the conduct directed 
  at the Atkinsons, it is inadmissible.
For the following reasons, we find Orkinâ€™s initiative 
  directing agents to breach the fixed-rate provision (Orkinâ€™s past conduct) is 
  dissimilar from Orkinâ€™s breach of the transferability provision in the present 
  case.Â  First, Orkinâ€™s past â€œinitiativeâ€ conduct was directed toward existing 
  customers, while Orkinâ€™sÂ  â€œtransferabilityâ€ conduct in the present case only 
  affected the Atkinsons, who were prospective customers.Â  In addition, those 
  affected by Orkinâ€™s past conduct would have coverage but for a higher price, 
  while the conduct here forced the Atkinsons to negotiate coverage from an entirely 
  different provider.Â  Finally, Orkinâ€™s past conduct involved an attempt to make 
  unprofitable contracts profitable, while the conduct in the present case was 
  an attempt to get out of an unprofitable contract.Â  
Second, Orkinâ€™s past conduct arose from an initiative 
  developed almost fifteen years before Orkin dishonored the transferability provision 
  in the present case.Â  In addition, Orkin was enjoined from unilaterally raising 
  rates more than ten years before Orkin had any contractual obligation with the 
  Atkinsons.Â  We find that the considerable period of time between Orkinâ€™s past 
  conduct and Orkinâ€™s conduct in the present case lends further support to our 
  finding that the two are dissimilar.
Allowing the jury to consider 
  evidence of Orkinâ€™s breach of the fixed-rate provision was extremely prejudicial 
  because it allowed the jury to punish Orkin for conduct unrelated to the conduct 
  in the present case.Â  Moreover, at trial, the Atkinsons did not present any 
  evidence that Orkin refused to honor the transferability provision on other 
  contracts in South Carolina.Â  The fact that Orkin stood to gain financially 
  from breaching both provisions of the contract is not sufficient to render the 
  two breaches â€œsimilar.â€Â  Accordingly, we hold that the trial court erred in 
  allowing the Atkinsons to present evidence of the Orkin initiative and, in doing 
  so, permitted the Atkinsons to unfairly exaggerate the degree of reprehensibility 
  of Orkinâ€™s conduct.
(b)Â  Expert Testimony
Orkin argues that the trial 
  judge erred in admitting into evidence Woodsideâ€™s expert testimony concerning 
  Orkinâ€™s projected losses for honoring the fixed-rate provision of all its pre-1975 
  contracts.Â  We agree. 
It is well settled that 
  â€œopinion testimony of an expert may be based upon a hypothetical question.â€Â  
  Gazes v. Dillardâ€™s Depâ€™t Store, Inc., 341 S.C. 507, 514, 534 S.E.2d 306, 
  310 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  But â€œthe hypothetical question must be based on facts 
  supported by the evidence â€¦.â€Â  Id.
We hold that Woodsideâ€™s 
  testimony as to Orkinâ€™s projected loss from honoring the fixed-rate provision 
  of its contracts is inadmissible for the same reasons we find the 1980 initiative 
  was inadmissible.Â  This projection is based upon conduct that is too dissimilar 
  from the conduct in the present case and is therefore, inadmissible because 
  it unfairly inflates the reprehensibility of Orkinâ€™s conduct in the present 
  case.
On the other hand, we are 
  much more hesitant to restrict outright Woodsideâ€™s testimony concerning Orkinâ€™s 
  gain from breaching the transferability provision in all its pre-1975 contracts.Â  
  This testimony - subject to the evidentiary safeguards of Gazes and Campbell 
  - could be probative of the reprehensibility of Orkinâ€™s conduct in the present 
  case.
  2.   Disparity between compensatory and punitive damage awards
The jury awarded the Atkinsons $786,500 in punitive 
  damages and $6,191 in compensatory damages, representing a 127 to 1 ratio. [8] Â  We hold that such a sizable disparity between 
  punitive and compensatory damages establishes a presumption that the punitive 
  damages award is an unconstitutional deprivation of property. 
The Campbell opinion provides that â€œfew 
  awards exceeding a single-digit ratio between punitive and compensatory damages, 
  to a significant degree, will satisfy due process.â€ 
  [9]  538 U.S. at 424 (quoting Gore, 517 U.S. at 582).Â Â  Nevertheless, 
  â€œthe Constitutional line [setting forth the appropriate ratio of actual to punitive 
  damages] is not marked by a simple mathematical formula.â€ Id.Â  The Court 
  emphasized that â€œbecause there are no rigid benchmarks that a punitive damages 
  award may not surpass, ratios greater than those we have previously upheld may 
  comport with due process where a particularly egregious act has resulted in 
  only a small amount of economic damages.â€ Id.Â  
Recently, the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals 
  upheld a punitive damages award that exceeded a single-digit ratio where a particularly 
  egregious act resulted in small economic damages. Mathias, 347 
  F.3d at 678.Â  In that case, the plaintiff suffered bites from hundreds of bed 
  bugs when he and his family rented a hotel room from the defendant.Â  The court 
  upheld a punitive damages award that exceeded a single-digit ratio because â€œ[t]he 
  defendantâ€™s behavior was outrageous but the compensable harm done was slight 
  and at the same time difficult to quantify because a large element of it was 
  emotional.â€Â  Id. at 677.
Although the amount of compensatory damages in the 
  present case was particularly low, Orkinâ€™s acts were not so egregious as to 
  warrant a 127 to 1 ratio.Â  Therefore, we hold that the Atkinsons have failed 
  to rebut the presumption that the three-digit, punitive-compensatory damages 
  ratios in this case is unconstitutional.Â  
  3.     Sanctions for Comparable Misconduct  
Finally, Campbell requires us to consider 
  cases involving comparable conduct to determine whether the ratio in the case 
  before us is unconstitutional.Â  After reviewing cases involving breach of contract 
  with a fraudulent act, we find that the 1 to 127 ratio awarded in this case 
  is well above the average compensatory-punitive damages ratio.Â  See, e.g., 
  Cock-N-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 1, 466 S.E.2d 
  727 (1996) (upholding a punitive damage award that was approximately 28 times 
  compensatory damages); Pinkney v. Orkin Exterminating Co., 268 S.C. 430, 
  234 S.E.2d 654 (1977) (upholding an award of $5,000 compensatory damages and 
  $4,000 punitive damages).Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  The Collateral Source Rule
The Atkinsons argue that proceeds from their settlement with Terminix 
  was a â€œcollateral source,â€ and therefore Orkin was not entitled to any set-off.Â  
  We agree.Â  
According to the collateral source rule, a wrongdoer 
  should not receive a windfall simply because the injured party received compensation 
  from an independent source.Â  Rattenni v. Grainger, 298 S.C. 276, 379 
  S.E.2d 890 (1989).Â  Moreover, this rule has been liberally applied in South 
  Carolina to preclude the reduction of damages.Â  See Otis Elevator v. Hardin 
  Constr. Co., 316 S.C. 292, 450 S.E.2d 41 (1994) (contractual right to indemnification 
  not defeated by fact that loss was actually paid by an insurance company); Rattenni, 
  298 S.C. at 277, 379 S.E.2d at 892 (1989) (tortfeasorâ€™s liability for damages 
  not reduced by underinsurance proceeds); Powers v. Temple, 250 S.C. 149, 
  156 S.E.2d 759 (1976) (tortfeasorâ€™s liability for damages not reduced by disability 
  payments from employer).Â  To qualify as a collateral source, the source must 
  be â€œwholly independent of the wrongdoer.â€Â  Citizens and S. Natâ€™l Bank of 
  South Carolina v. Gregory, 320 S.C. 90, 92, 463 S.E.2d 317, 318 (1995).Â  

In a post-trial motion, Orkin asked the court to reduce the judgment by 
  the amount the Atkinsons recovered from their settlement with Terminix. Because 
  the judge viewed Terminix and Orkin as joint tortfeasors, the judge reduced 
  the amount Orkin owed by the amount Terminix had already paid in settlement.Â  
  The trial judge also reasoned that the negligence claim was â€œgeneral in natureâ€ 
  and that â€œTerminixâ€™s conduct could be a contributing factor in this cause of 
  action and, thus, a contributing factor to Plaintiffâ€™s damages under the negligence 
  cause of action.â€ 
We find that the trial judge erred in treating 
  Orkin and Terminix as joint-tortfeasors.Â  The duties that Orkin and Terminix 
  owed the Atkinsons were based upon independent, unrelated contracts, not a common 
  duty of care.Â  Moreover, we see no indication that the claims against Terminix 
  constituted a â€œcontributing factorâ€ to Orkinâ€™s negligent inspection of the house. 
  Accordingly, we hold that the proceeds from the Terminix settlement was a collateral 
  source, and therefore the trial court erred in offseting the judgment, by the 
  amount the Atkinsons received in settlement.Â  
Conclusion
We recognize that Orkinâ€™s 
  breach of the transferability provision in the contract with the Atkinsons will 
  support a jury award of significant punitive damages.Â  Nevertheless, after applying 
  the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s holding in Campbell, we reverse and 
  remand this case on the issue of the amount of punitive damages awarded, with 
  instructions that on retrial of the issue of the amount of punitive damages, 
  evidence of Orkinâ€™s 1980 initiative and Woodsideâ€™s expert testimony concerning 
  Orkinâ€™s current and potential losses for honoring the fixed-rate provision of 
  its pre-1975 contracts must not be admitted.Â  
We also reverse the trial 
  courtâ€™s decision to offset the proceeds from the Atkinsonsâ€™ settlement with 
  Terminix.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the juryâ€™s award of $75,259.33 in actual damages 
  without setting off that amount by the $31,111.75 the Atkinsons received in 
  their settlement with Terminix.
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT 
  and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Initially, the Atkinsons sued both Terminix Service, Inc. (Terminix) 
    and Orkin but settled with Terminix for $31,111.75 before trial. 

 
    [2] In 1975, Orkin changed its contracts omitting the fixed-rate 
    provision and including language allowing Orkin to unilaterally increase renewal 
    rates.

 
   [3]  The trial court found that Beck, as manager of Orkinâ€™s Charleston 
    branch, was Orkinâ€™s agent, and therefore Orkin was vicariously liable for 
    Beckâ€™s actions.

 
   [4]  The trial judge found that Orkin abused the discovery process 
    and sanctioned Orkin $25,000.Â  

 
   [5]  The negligence award breaks down into $10,268.33 for expenses 
    the Atkinsons incurred before trial and $58,800 in repair costs.

 
    [6] The trial judge permitted the jury to review Orkinâ€™s 1999 
    financial statement during its consideration of punitive damages.Â  The punitive 
    damages award constituted one percent of Orkinâ€™s net worth that year.

 
   [7]  The Campbell Court used the word â€œguidepostâ€ to emphasize 
    its intent to create a guide, not a bright-line rule.Â  Campbell, 538 
    U.S. at 424.Â  For example, Judge Posner of the Seventh Circuit recently explained 
    that it is not necessary for courts to follow rigid mathematical rules when 
    reviewing a punitive damages award:Â  â€œWhat follows from these principles, 
    however, is that punitive damages should be admeasured by standards or rules 
    rather than in a completely ad hoc manner, and this does not tell us what 
    the maximum ratio of punitive to compensatory damages should be in a particular 
    case.â€Â  Mathias, 347 F.3d at 676.

 
   [8]  The jury found for the Atkinsons on both the breach of contract 
    accompanied by a fraudulent act and negligence claims.Â  The punitive damages 
    award attached to the breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act claim, 
    which was the only cause of action in the complaint that warrants punitive 
    damages. See Scott v. Porter, 340 S.C. 158, 172, 530 S.E.2d 
    389, 396 (2000) (holding that it is only proper for a jury to award punitive 
    damages for a negligence claim when that negligence was wilful, wanton, or 
    reckless); Wright v. Public Savings Life Ins. Co., 262 S.C. 285, 289, 
    204 S.E.2d 57, 59 (1974) (holding punitive damages may be awarded when a breach 
    of contract is accompanied by a fraudulent act).Â  Therefore, we did not include 
    the juryâ€™s compensatory damages award as to Orkinâ€™s simple negligence in our 
    computation of the ratio. 

 
   [9]  The Campbell Court recites a long history of statutory 
    sanctions concerning double, treble, or quadruple damages awarded to deter 
    and punish.Â  The Court provides that â€œwhile they are not binding, they are 
    instructiveâ€ in that they all provide single-digit ratios. Campbell, 
    538 U.S. at 425.Â

title: State v. Downs
description: The Court affirmed Appellant's death sentence.  Appellant's guilty plea was not a conditional plea, and he was not deprived of his right to a jury trial.  Further, the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to sentence Appellant to death.  Finally, the death penalty was proportionate to Appellant's crime.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William E. Downs, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25884
Heard September 21, 2004 - Filed October 
  25, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, and Jeffrey P. Bloom, both of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES: This is a death penalty case.Â  Appellant pleaded 
  guilty to murder, kidnapping, and first-degree criminal sexual conduct with 
  a minor.Â  With respect to the murder, the circuit court found the following 
  aggravating circumstances: Appellant committed the murder while in the commission 
  of criminal sexual conduct; Appellant committed the murder while in the commission 
  of a kidnapping; and Appellant murdered a child eleven years old or younger.Â  
  The circuit court sentenced Appellant to death. 
  [1] Â  This opinion consolidates Appellantâ€™s direct appeal and the sentence 
  review required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25 (2003).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The victim, a six-year-old boy, was taken into a wooded area of a park, raped, 
  and strangled to death.Â  After newspapers reported the murder, Appellant told 
  his sister that he had committed the crime.Â  Appellantâ€™s sister reported this 
  to the police and disclosed Appellantâ€™s location.Â  The police found and detained 
  Appellant, and he confessed.Â  
Appellant was charged with murder, kidnapping, and first-degree criminal sexual 
  conduct with a minor.Â  At the plea hearing, Appellant expressed the desire to 
  plead guilty but was uncertain whether he wanted to later present evidence that 
  he was mentally ill at the time of the crime (guilty but mentally ill or GBMI). 
  [2] Â  Appellant never suggested that he wanted to plead guilty only if found 
  mentally ill.Â  Rather, Appellant repeatedly stated that he knew he wanted to 
  admit guilt.Â  Moreover, Appellant claimed to understand that if he were to present 
  evidence of mental illness and the court were to find him GBMI, death would 
  remain a possible sentence. [3] 
The court proceeded with the hearing on the guilty plea while permitting Appellant 
  to defer the decision whether to claim mental illness.Â  Upon the courtâ€™s inquiry 
  Appellant claimed to understand that by pleading guilty he waived his right 
  to a jury trial on both guilt and sentencing.Â  When the judge asked if Appellant 
  wanted to impanel a jury, admit guilt, and ask the jury to decide the sentence, 
  Appellant answered in the negative.Â  The court accepted Appellantâ€™s guilty plea 
  as voluntarily, knowingly, and intelligently entered.Â  
At a later hearing, Appellant did present evidence that he was mentally ill 
  when the crime occurred.Â  An expert testified that Appellantâ€™s mental condition 
  rendered him unable to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law, that 
  is, he was mentally ill.Â  Two other experts testified that Appellant was not 
  mentally ill, that he could so conform his conduct.Â  After considering the evidence, 
  the court ruled that Appellant failed to prove he was GBMI. 
  [4] Â Â Â Â Â  
At sentencing the court found the three aggravating circumstances stated above.Â  
  In addition, even though Appellantâ€™s attorneys represented that Appellant had 
  instructed them to neither â€œoffer any mitigation to the courtâ€ nor â€œargue to 
  the court for a sentence of life without parole,â€ the court found four mitigating 
  circumstances. [5] Â  After considering both sets of circumstances, 
  the court sentenced Appellant to death.Â  
ISSUES

  
     Whether Appellantâ€™s guilty plea was an invalid conditional plea.
    
  
    Whether Appellant had a right to a jury trial on sentencing of which 
  he was deprived.
    
  
    Whether the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to sentence 
  Appellant to death because the indictment did not allege aggravating circumstances.

ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Plea
Appellant claims his guilty plea was a conditional plea and therefore 
  invalid.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, guilty pleas must be unconditional.Â  State v. Peppers, 
  346 S.C. 502, 504, 552 S.E.2d 288, 289 (2001); State v. Oâ€™Leary, 
  302 S.C. 17, 18, 393 S.E.2d 186, 187 (1990); State v. Truesdale, 
  278 S.C. 368, 370, 296 S.E.2d 528, 529 (1982).Â  If â€œan accused attempts to attach 
  any condition or qualificationâ€ to a guilty plea, then â€œthe trial court should 
  direct a plea of not guilty.â€Â  Truesdale, 278 S.C. at 370, 296 S.E.2d 
  at 529.Â  If the trial court accepts a conditional guilty plea, then the plea 
  will be vacated on appeal.Â  Peppers, 346 S.C. at 505, 552 S.E.2d at 290.Â Â Â Â  

Appellant asserts his plea was conditional because he pleaded guilty while 
  deferring the decision whether to present evidence of mental illness.Â  Appellant 
  argues the potential of being found mentally ill constituted a condition attached 
  to his plea.Â  We disagree.Â  
Appellant never attempted to reserve the right to later deny his guilt.Â  He 
  reserved the right only to present evidence that he committed the crime while 
  mentally ill.Â  Guilty but mentally ill is still guilty.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 17-24-70 (2003) (requiring that a GBMI defendant be sentenced as guilty); 
  see also State v. Hornsby, 326 S.C. 121, 126, 484 S.E.2d 869, 
  872 (1997) (noting that a finding of GBMI â€œdoes not absolve a defendant of guiltâ€).Â  
  The difference between guilty and GBMI pertains only to post-sentencing medical 
  treatment.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-24-70 (2003).Â  Appellantâ€™s guilty 
  plea was unconditional.
II.Â  The Sentencing Procedure
Appellant asserts Ring v. Arizona, 536 U.S. 584, 122 S. Ct. 2428, 153 
  L.Ed.2d 556 (2002), renders unconstitutional the requirement in S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 16-3-20(B) (2003) that the sentencing proceeding be held before the judge 
  when a defendant pleads guilty to murder.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â  
The capital-sentencing procedure invalidated in Ring does not exist 
  in South Carolina.Â  Arizonaâ€™s statute required the judge to factually determine 
  whether there existed an aggravating circumstance supporting the death penalty 
  regardless whether the judge or a jury had determined guilt.Â  Ariz. Rev. Stat. 
  Â§ 13-703(C) (2001) (amended 2002); Ring, 536 U.S. at 597, 122 S. Ct. 
  at 2437, 153 L.Ed.2d at 569.Â  In South Carolina, conversely, a defendant convicted 
  by a jury can be sentenced to death only if the jury also finds an aggravating 
  circumstance and recommends the death penalty.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(B) 
  (2003); Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 652, 594 S.E.2d 462, 466 (2004).Â Â Â Â Â  

In any event, Ring did not involve jury-trial waivers and is not implicated 
  when a defendant pleads guilty.Â  Other courts have also reached this conclusion.Â  
  See, e.g., Leone v. Indiana, 797 N.E.2d 743, 749-50 (Ind. 
  2003); Colwell v. Nevada, 118 Nev. 807, 59 P.3d 463, 473-74 (Nev. 2003); 
  Illinois v. Altom, 338 Ill.App.3d 355, 362, 788 N.E.2d 55, 61 (Ill. App. 
  5 Dist. 2003), app. denied, 203 Ill.2d 663, 792 N.E.2d 308 (Ill. 2003).Â  

Appellant was informed that by pleading guilty he waived his right to a jury 
  trial on both guilt and sentencing.Â  He does not argue his waiver was made involuntarily, 
  unknowingly, or unintelligently.Â  See Burnett v. State, 352 S.C. 
  589, 576 S.E.2d 144 (2003) (discussing waivers of constitutional rights).Â  Appellant 
  was not deprived of his right to a jury trial.
III.Â  The Indictment
Appellant argues the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to sentence him to death because the indictment charging him with murder 
  [6]  did not allege an aggravating circumstance. [7] Â  Appellant did not challenge 
  the indictment below, but subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time, 
  including on appeal.Â  See Koon v. State, 358 S.C. 359, 365, 595 
  S.E.2d 456, 459 (2004).Â  We disagree with Appellant on the merits. 
Appellant asserts Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466, 120 S. Ct. 2348, 
  147 L.Ed.2d 435 (2000), and Ring v. Arizona, supra, mandate 
  that indictments in state capital cases allege aggravation.Â  Appellant is incorrect.Â  
  The Court expressly noted in both Apprendi and Ring that the cases 
  did not involve challenges to state indictments.Â  Apprendi, 530 U.S. 
  at 477, 120 S. Ct. at 2356, 147 L.Ed.2d at 447 n. 3; Ring, 536 U.S. at 
  597, 122 S. Ct. at 2437, 153 L.Ed.2d at 569 n. 4.Â  More important, the Fourteenth 
  Amendment has not been construed to incorporate the Fifth Amendmentâ€™s Presentment 
  or Indictment Clause.Â  See Apprendi, 530 U.S. at 477, 120 S. Ct. 
  at 2356, 147 L.Ed.2d at 447 n. 3; Ring, 530 U.S. at 597, 122 S. Ct. at 
  2437, 153 L.Ed.2d at 569 n. 4; Alexander v. Louisiana, 405 U.S. 
  625, 633, 92 S. Ct. 1221, 1226-27, 31 L.Ed.2d 536, 543-44 (1972); Hurtado 
  v. California, 110 U.S. 516, 534-35, 4 S. Ct. 111, 120-21, 28 L.Ed. 232, 
  238 (1884).Â  State law governs indictments for state-law crimes.Â  
Under South Carolina law, aggravating circumstances need 
  not be alleged in an indictment for murder.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-30 (2003); 
  State v. Butler, 277 S.C. 452, 456-57, 290 S.E.2d 1, 3-4 (1982) (subsequent 
  history omitted).Â  The aggravating circumstances listed in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  16-3-20(C)(a) (2003) are sentencing factors, not elements of murder.Â  See 
  Butler, 277 S.C. atÂ  456-67, 290 S.E.2d at 3-4.Â  The circuit court had 
  subject matter jurisdiction to sentence Appellant to death.
SENTENCE REVIEW
The Court must conduct a proportionality review of Appellantâ€™s death sentence 
  based on the record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(A) (2003).Â  In conducting the 
  review, the Court considers similar cases in which the death penalty has been 
  upheld.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(E) (2003).
We find Appellantâ€™s death sentence was not the result of passion, 
  prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor, and the evidence supports the trial 
  judgeâ€™s findings of aggravation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C) 
  (2003).Â  Further, in relation to sentences in similar cases, Appellantâ€™s was 
  neither excessive nor disproportionate to his crime.Â  See State 
  v. Passaro, 350 S.C. 499, 567 S.E.2d 862 (2002); State v. Stokes, 
  345 S.C. 368, 548 S.E.2d 202 (2001); State v. Rogers, 338 S.C. 435, 527 
  S.E.2d 101 (2000); State v. Rosemond, 335 S.C. 593, 518 S.E.2d 
  588 (1999); State v. Charping, 333 S.C. 124, 508 S.E.2d 851 (1998), cert. 
  denied, Charping v. South Carolina, 527 U.S. 1007, 119 S. Ct. 2345, 
  144 L.Ed.2d 241 (1999); State v. Conyers, 326 S.C. 263, 487 S.E.2d 181 
  (1997).
CONCLUSION
Appellantâ€™s guilty plea was not a conditional 
  plea, and Appellant was not deprived of his right to a jury trial.Â  In addition, 
  the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to sentence Appellant to death.Â  
  Finally, the punishment was proportionate to the crime.Â  Appellantâ€™s guilty 
  plea and sentence are
AFFIRMED. 
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Appellant was not sentenced for the kidnapping 
    or first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-910 
    (2003) does not permit a sentence for kidnapping if the defendant is sentenced 
    for murder. 

 
   [2]  A defendant is GBMI if at the time of the offense, 
    â€œhe had the capacity to distinguish right from wrong or to recognize his act 
    as being wrong as defined in Section 17-24-10(A), but because of mental disease 
    or defect he lacked sufficient capacity to conform his conduct to the requirements 
    of the law.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-24-20(A) (2003).

 
   [3]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-24-70 (2003) requires that 
    a defendant found GBMI be sentenced â€œas provided by law for a defendant found 
    guilty.â€Â  This Court has held it is constitutional to sentence a GBMI defendant 
    to death.Â  State v. Wilson, 306 S.C. 498, 512, 413 S.E.2d 19, 27 (1992) 
    (subsequent history omitted).

 
   [4]  The defendant has the burden of proving mental 
    illness by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-24-20(D) 
    (2003).

 
   [5]  First, Appellant had â€œno significant history of prior criminal 
    conviction involving the use of violence against another person.â€Â  Second, 
    Appellant committed the murder while â€œunder the influence of mental or emotional 
    disturbance.â€Â  Third, Appellantâ€™s capacity â€œto appreciate the criminality 
    of his act or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law was substantially 
    impaired.â€Â  And fourth, Appellantâ€™s age or mentality at the time of the crime 
    weighed in his favor.Â  

 
   [6]  The indictment stated Appellant â€œdid in Aiken 
    County on or about April 17, 1999, with malice aforethought, kill [the victim] 
    by means of asphyxia due to manual strangulation and said victim died as a 
    proximate result thereof.Â  All in violation of Section 16-3-10 of the South 
    Carolina Code of Laws (1976), as amended.â€

 
    [7]    The State timely gave Appellant notice of aggravation 
    pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(B) (2003).
